reviewText: There is absolutely no way I can be objective about this movie; it has been a part of my life since I was a child. My mother took me to see it and we both spent a lot of movie time just sobbing as the story unfolded. I still remember the small neighborhood theater where we watched the movie and our quiet walk home in the dark holding hands. Quite frankly I cannot explain the powerful impact that evening had on me as a child but it did and those memories are still remarkably clear.The music has also been firmly embedded in my memory all those years, I'm almost 80 years old, and the music has served as a gentle reminder of my mother and the things I shared with her as her child.For some reason, only now have I ordered a copy of the movie for my collection. I have absolutely no interest in any controversy surrounding the movie or the devices that may have been used to promote it or facilitate the performance of the aging Jeanette MacDonald. The movie experience itself has always been sufficient for me to remember the movie fondly and to fully enjoy it once more as I viewed the DVD copy I got from Amazon.There is nothing I would complain about in this recording of the movie; it brought back a flood of memories and yes, I did cry again as I watched the movie. Some things never change, I guess.As a movie experience I recommend the movie with great enthusiasm; especially if you enjoy a tenderly done love story that is filled with pathos. Watching the movie after all these years brought back many loving memories of my mother and will remain a choice part of my movie collection.

reviewText: This marvelous MGM restored film is a must for any fans of MGM studios and the high production values they turn out over and over again.The film is shot in the most gorgeous Technicolor and has been lit in a way not seen for many years.Jeanette sings the all her songs in the manner which exceeds expectations, and although this is a play with music the musical content is exquisite.The supporting cast are all seasoned players who turn in great performances, and I define anyone not to burst into tears at the end of the film.Recommended,an excellent film not seen for a very long time.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Gene Raymond was a handsome, well built thirties leading man (the top billed star of "Flying Down To Rio" which is better remembered for teaming Astaire and Rogers for the first time...though Raymond displays a well polished physique and nice personality opposite the exotic Delores Del Rio)...who found his greatest claim to fame as his screen career was fading...He Married Jeanette MacDonald.The fans were less than thrilled...they expected dear Jeanette to be forever united with Nelson Eddy (and there is some evidence and conjecture that the singing sweethearts may have actually been in love off screen...and it has been claimed that Nelson was the actual physical father of her children)...In any case...this film gave the MacDonald fans their only chance to see her with the man she was married to...(though not in the lead role...that went to urbane Brian Aherne)..otherwise this is a so so remake of a Norma Shearer vehicle...worth seeing for the cast and the luscious technicolor....
